newsitem.title: KENYA: Kenya says tackling graft, IMF demands political move.
newsitem.headline: Kenya says tackling graft, IMF demands political move.

text.p: Kenya sought on Thursday more time to meet International Monetary Fund demands to combat corruption or lose a key aid package but said much of what the IMF wanted was political.
The IMF demanded last month Kenya take action by Thursday to show its commitment to fight corruption and reform the energy sector or it would let a three-year aid package worth $205 million lapse.
Finance Minister Musalia Mudavadi said Kenya had asked the IMF to extend the deadline and was waiting for an answer. "I am crossing my fingers," he said.
"We are in the middle of consultations. We are still talking with (IMF headquarters in) Washington," said the minister, adding that negotiations on the aid package had not collapsed.
In Washington, an IMF spokesman said the Fund was considering the Kenyan request.

Fares Kuindwa, head of the civil service and secretary to the cabinet, later told a news conference that 90 percent of what was demanded by the IMF to continue with the aid package was political and its language could "be a lot more diplomatic".
Kenya's opposition says corruption extends to the highest levels of government and this is why President Daniel arap Moi's government has failed to fulfill promises to combat all sleaze.

Kuindwa said Moi received a letter from the IMF on Tuesday with a reply expected on Wednesday and the president replied on Thursday. "For a sovereign nation, the timing is rather intriguing," he said.
He criticised the letter to the president, saying it would have better been addressed to the finance minister. "The issues raised (by the IMF) are 90 percent political," he added.

He said Kenya was committed to cutting corruption and wanted to resolve in court the Goldenberg scandal in which about $100 million was paid to a company in compensation for gold and diamond exports. Kenya produces little gold and has no diamonds.
Kuindwa listed other corruption-related cases and said they were being tackled and the government did not condone graft.
The shilling fell against the dollar and pound on Thursday because of market uncertainty ahead of the IMF decision. It weakened to 58.92 to the dollar from Wednesday's 58.06.
The IMF extended a three-year Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) loan worth $205 million in April last year but payments were conditional on Kenya meeting promises on reform.
The last scheduled ESAF payment, $36 million, was delayed by the IMF for a month from June 30, mainly because of its concern at the way Kenyan authorities had handled the Goldenberg scandal.
The IMF had demanded the government "take decisive steps to ensure transparency and accountability in the use of public funds and to resolve outstanding energy sector reform".
Mudavadi said losing the ESAF would be a big blow to Kenya, where Moi, 73, the country's ruler for 19 years, seeks re-election this year in the face of opposition demands for political reforms.
"This could have serious repercussions. It could dent investor confidence, affect the shilling, affect inflation and it is something that could shake confidence in the economy," he said.
He added the government was drafting a bill to combat corruption but this was not enough to meet the IMF demands.
The IMF has quoted Goldenberg International to illustrate how Kenyan authorities were reluctant to punish corruption.
The IMF delayed releasing the $36 million ESAF tranche after the high court decided on June 20 to end the prosecution of a businessman and former officials implicated in the scandal.
The businessman and former officials have been charged again. ($1=58.9 Kenyan Shillings)
